generif.text: Meta-analysis and HuGE review of genotype prevalence and gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
A family with posterior polar cataract with a novel deletion mutation in PITX3.
we mapped dominant congenital posterior polar cataracts to chromosome 10q24. On sequencing the coding region of PITX3, we found a 17-base-pair duplication in exon 4.
Nurr1 and Pitx3 cooperatively promote terminal maturation to the midbrain dopamine neuron phenotype in murine and human ES cell cultures.
This is the first report of homozygous PITX3 mutations in humans. The phenotype in these individuals highlights the role of PITX3 in ocular and central nervous system (CNS) development.
The 657ins17bp duplication of the PITX3 gene is the cause of the cataract phenotype in the large pedigree.
we discuss the role of Pitx3 in molecular mechanisms involved in the regional specification, neuronal specification and differentiation of mDA neurons--REVIEW

The G219fs mutation was found in multiple families affected with congenital cataracts along with anterior segment malformations. The S13N mutant showed only minor alteration and may represent a rare polymorphism in the PITX3 gene.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
We provide evidence for a novel, strong and reproducible association of the PITX3 promoter SNP rs3758549: C>T (p=0.004) with Parkinson Disease.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
The A-allele of a HapMap tagging SNP (rs4919621) that was genotyped in a population of Parkinson's disease (PD) patients, was significantly more common in PD patients with an early age of onset.

Duplication of a segment of PITX3 can result in severe symptoms leading to functional blindness while in other individuals in the same family or in other families, the same duplication leads to treatable cataract with minimal visual impairment.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
The result of this study found a strong association between the PITX3 promoter rs3758549 polymorphism and Parkinson's disease.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
PITX3 may play a role in the pathogenesis of Parkinson disease.
The absence of PITX3 mutations in a family presenting congenital cataract and mental retardation, is reported.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Genetic variation in PITX3 may increase the risk of developing schizophrenia.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
The single nucleotide polymorphism rs3758549 (C >T substitution) in the Pitx3 gene is a potential risk for sporadic Parkinson disease (PD), especially early-onset PD in Chinese Han population.
This study found that rs2281983 and rs4919621 appeared to confer susceptibility to Parkinson's disease, especially in early-onset Parkinson's disease and familial Parkinson's disease.
This study suggested that the PITX3 gene rs3758549 polymorphism may increase the susceptibility of Parkinson's disease in chinese.

Allele & genotype frequencies did not differ between patients & controls for rs2281983, rs4919621, & rs3758549. These SNP sites do not contribute to the risk of developing PD in late-onset sporadic PD in this Chinese population.
The 542delC is a novel mutation in PITX3 causing an isolated posterior polar cataract.
Data show that BFSP2 and PITX3, hitherto known to cause eye defects only in a dominant fashion, can also present recessively.
The results of this study suggested that these PITX3 SNPs do not contribute to the risk of developing PD in EOPD or LOPD in Chinese.
we report the absence of mutations in all studied genes in four families with phenotypes associating cataract, mental retardation and microcephaly.
Deletion of PITX3 is associated with aggressive neurobehavioral phenotype in Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
This study provided that NURR1 and PITX3 gene expression is decreased in the peripheral blood lymphocytes of Chinese patients with Parkinson's disease patients.
novel synonymous SNP in PITX3 gene may contribute to PD risk in the Chinese population.

Presence of the rs4919621 allele A in PITX3 significantly increases the risk of Parkinson's disease (PD) patients in a Caucasian population, while rs2281983 allele C and rs4919621 allele A were both risk factors in early onset PD.
Mutations in PITX3 are not a common cause or a risk factor for multisystem atrophy and progressive supranuclear palsy in the Polish population.

our data demonstrate that key midbrain dopamine regulators (Nurr1, Pitx3, and Lmx1a) play overlapping as well as distinct roles during neurogenesis and neurotransmitter phenotype determination of mDA neurons
the SNP rs3758549 might contribute to the occurrence of Parkinson disease (PD) in the Asian population, especially early onset PD in the Asian population.
Meta-analysis suggests that rs3758549, rs2281983, and rs4919621 single nucleotide polymorphisms are not major determinants of the risk for Parkinson's disease
novel PITX3 mutation c.573del, p.(Ser192Alafs*117), was identified in heterozygous state in a Belgo-Romanian family with a similar phenotype
PITX3 variants rs3758549 and rs4919621 are not associated with ET in Chinese Han population.
Study showed that PITX3 and PITX2 were hypermethylated in prostate carcinomas (PCa) and significantly associated with established clinicopathologic parameters characteristic of PCa.

Study showed that PITX3 methylation was significantly methylated in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) tumor compared to normal adjacent tissue and correlated with lymph node status. These results provide evidence that PITX3 DNA methylation is an independent prognostic biomarker for overall survival in patients with HNSCC and might aid in the process of risk stratification for individualized treatment.
These findings suggest that p.A203fs in PITX3 is the cause of cataracts in the recruited family.

Results show that a common polymorphism in the PITX3 gene affects the risk of developing Parkinson's disease (PD) dementia and visuospatial dysfunction in idiopathic PD. If validated, these findings can provide new insights into the neurobiology and genetics of non-motor symptoms in PD.
Heterozygous mutation in the PITX3 gene is associated with ocular developmental defects.

The functional analysis of these 2 PITX3 mutations in the in vitro functional studies is an important complement and extension, which provides a potential interpretation for the pathogenesis and molecular mechanism of PITX3 mutations associated with CC.
The mutation c.797_814del, p.Ser266_Ala271del is a novel mutation in the conserved DNA-binding OAR domain of PITX3 that causes congenital cataract.
Complementation of dopaminergic signaling by Pitx3-GDNF synergy induces dopamine secretion by multipotent Ntera2 cells.
Variants in PAX6, PITX3 and HSF4 causing autosomal dominant congenital cataracts.

name: paired like homeodomain 3
summary: This gene encodes a member of the RIEG/PITX homeobox family, which is in the bicoid class of homeodomain proteins. Members of this family act as transcription factors. This protein is involved in lens formation during eye development. Mutations of this gene have been associated with anterior segment mesenchymal dysgenesis and congenital cataracts. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
